articles.headline: Redesigning Crops to Harvest Fuel
articles.snippet: Seed and biotech companies see a big opportunity in developing corn and other crops tailored for use in ethanol and other biofuels.
articles.abstract: Seed and biotech companies see a big opportunity in developing corn and other crops tailored for use in ethanol and other biofuels.

articles.headline: New Role for Rubin: Policy Guru
articles.snippet: Does former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin still matter? Many would probably say yes.  But just don’t ask the man himself.
articles.abstract: Does former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin still matter? Many would probably say yes.  But just don’t ask the man himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does Robert E. Rubin still matter?

articles.abstract: The targets included nine journalists who have covered Hewlett-Packard, including one from The New York Times.

articles.headline: Ad Firms to Hire More Black Managers in City
articles.snippet: Under the agreements, the agencies have agreed to submit to three years of monitoring by New York City.
articles.abstract: Under the agreements, the agencies have agreed to submit to three years of monitoring by New York City.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finding that just 2 percent of the upper echelon of the advertising industry is black, New York City officials said yesterday that they had reached agreements with several of the nation’s biggest ad firms forcing them to bring more black managers into this crucial sector of the city’s economy.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Blair to Give Up Post as Premier Within One Year
articles.snippet: The British prime minister has moved from political dominance to fighting off mockery about his closeness to President Bush.
articles.abstract: The British prime minister has moved from political dominance to fighting off mockery about his closeness to President Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Sept. 7 — Prime Minister Tony Blair announced Thursday that he would leave office within the next 12 months, bending to pressure after an open rebellion in his own party.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Finds an Ally in Conservatives
articles.snippet: As Wal-Mart struggles to rebut growing criticism, it has discovered a reliable ally: conservative research groups.
articles.abstract: As Wal-Mart struggles to rebut growing criticism, it has discovered a reliable ally: conservative research groups.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Don’t Like a Director? Spy on Him
articles.snippet: How can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors?
articles.abstract: How can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors?
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors? If you dissent on this board, we’ll nail you.

articles.headline: Ad Firms to Hire More Black Managers in City
articles.snippet: Finding that just 2 percent of the upper echelon of the advertising industry is black, New York City officials said yesterday that they had reached agreements with several of the nation's biggest ad firms forcing them to bring more black managers ...
articles.abstract: Finding that just 2 percent of the upper echelon of the advertising industry is black, New York City officials said yesterday that they had reached agreements with several of the nation's biggest ad firms forcing them to bring more black managers into this crucial sector of the city's economy.     The city's Human Rights Commission found that hiring of black workers had barely improved since an inquiry found similar problems 40 years ago. Of 8,000 employees working for 16 agencies the commission examined, Patricia L. Gatling, chairwoman of the commission, said about 22 percent make more than $100,000 a year, and only 2.5 percent of those are black.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finding that just 2 percent of the upper echelon of the advertising industry is black, New York City officials said yesterday that they had reached agreements with several of the nation's biggest ad firms forcing them to bring more black managers into this crucial sector of the city's economy.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Questions Raised About C.I.A. Prisons
articles.snippet: A review of public documents and interviews with American officials raises questions about President Bush's assertions on Wednesday that the C.I.A.'s secret network of prisons used lawful interrogation methods and was fully described to select mem...
articles.abstract: A review of public documents and interviews with American officials raises questions about President Bush's assertions on Wednesday that the C.I.A.'s secret network of prisons used lawful interrogation methods and was fully described to select members of Congress.   BY MARK MAZZETTI, PAGE A24
articles.lead_paragraph: A review of public documents and interviews with American officials raises questions about President Bush's assertions on Wednesday that the C.I.A.'s secret network of prisons used lawful interrogation methods and was fully described to select members of Congress. BY MARK MAZZETTI, PAGE A24

articles.headline: Don’t Like a Director? Spy on Him
articles.snippet: HOW can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors? If you dissent on this board, we'll nail you.     It seems that Hewlett-Packard's chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, was angry t...
articles.abstract: HOW can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors? If you dissent on this board, we'll nail you.     It seems that Hewlett-Packard's chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, was angry that somebody had been leaking information she wanted kept secret. So, Ms. Dunn decided to spy on her fellow directors, and the company hired investigators to find out who was leaking. It worked. The guilty director was identified and will not be renominated to the board.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW can you have independent directors when the board chairwoman feels free to order investigators to spy on the directors? If you dissent on this board, we'll nail you.

articles.headline: Lawyers and G.O.P. Chiefs Resist Tribunal Plan
articles.snippet: The Bush administration's proposal to bring leading terrorism suspects before military tribunals met stiff resistance Thursday from key Republicans and top military lawyers who said that some provisions would not withstand legal scrutiny or do eno...
articles.abstract: The Bush administration's proposal to bring leading terrorism suspects before military tribunals met stiff resistance Thursday from key Republicans and top military lawyers who said that some provisions would not withstand legal scrutiny or do enough to repair the nation's tarnished reputation internationally.     Democrats, meanwhile, said they were inclined to go along with Senate Republicans drafting an alternative to the White House plan, one that would allow defendants more rights. That left Republicans to argue among themselves about what the tribunals would look like, and threatened to rob the issue of the political momentum the White House hoped it would provide going into the closely fought midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 - The Bush administration's proposal to bring leading terrorism suspects before military tribunals met stiff resistance Thursday from key Republicans and top military lawyers who said that some provisions would not withstand legal scrutiny or do enough to repair the nation's tarnished reputation internationally.

articles.headline: Interrogation Methods Rejected by Military Win Bush’s Support
articles.snippet: Many of the harsh interrogation techniques repudiated by the Pentagon on Wednesday would be made lawful by legislation put forward the same day by the Bush administration. And the courts would be forbidden from intervening.      The proposal is in...
articles.abstract: Many of the harsh interrogation techniques repudiated by the Pentagon on Wednesday would be made lawful by legislation put forward the same day by the Bush administration. And the courts would be forbidden from intervening.      The proposal is in the last 10 pages of an 86-page bill devoted mostly to military commissions, and it is a tangled mix of cross-references and pregnant omissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of the harsh interrogation techniques repudiated by the Pentagon on Wednesday would be made lawful by legislation put forward the same day by the Bush administration. And the courts would be forbidden from intervening.

articles.headline: New Role for Rubin: Policy Guru
articles.snippet: Does Robert E. Rubin still matter?      Many would probably say yes. In Washington, Mr. Rubin, who was President Bill Clinton's Treasury secretary, has started a small research group aimed at generating policy ideas for Democratic presidential can...
articles.abstract: Does Robert E. Rubin still matter?      Many would probably say yes. In Washington, Mr. Rubin, who was President Bill Clinton's Treasury secretary, has started a small research group aimed at generating policy ideas for Democratic presidential candidates, as well as elevating the next generation of Democrat-supporting financiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does Robert E. Rubin still matter?

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard Spied on Writers in Leaks
articles.snippet: The California attorney general's investigation into the purloining of private phone records by agents of Hewlett-Packard has revealed that the monitoring effort began earlier than previously indicated and included journalists as targets.      The...
articles.abstract: The California attorney general's investigation into the purloining of private phone records by agents of Hewlett-Packard has revealed that the monitoring effort began earlier than previously indicated and included journalists as targets.      The targets included nine journalists who have covered Hewlett-Packard, including one from The New York Times, the company said.

articles.headline: Redesigning Crops to Harvest Fuel
articles.snippet: More miles to the bushel.      That is the new mission of crop scientists. In an era of $3-a-gallon gasoline and growing concern about global warming from fossil fuels, seed and biotechnology companies see a big new opportunity in developing corn ...
articles.abstract: More miles to the bushel.      That is the new mission of crop scientists. In an era of $3-a-gallon gasoline and growing concern about global warming from fossil fuels, seed and biotechnology companies see a big new opportunity in developing corn and other crops tailored for use in ethanol and other biofuels.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Finds an Ally in Conservatives
articles.snippet: As Wal-Mart Stores struggles to rebut criticism from unions and Democratic leaders, the company has discovered a reliable ally: prominent conservative research groups like the American Enterprise Institute, the Heritage Foundation and the Manhatta...
articles.abstract: As Wal-Mart Stores struggles to rebut criticism from unions and Democratic leaders, the company has discovered a reliable ally: prominent conservative research groups like the American Enterprise Institute, the Heritage Foundation and the Manhattan Institute.     Top policy analysts at these groups have written newspaper opinion pieces around the country supporting Wal-Mart, defended the company in interviews with reporters and testified on its behalf before government committees in Washington.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Blair to Give Up Post as Premier Within One Year
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Tony Blair announced Thursday that he would leave office within the next 12 months, bending to pressure after an open rebellion in his own party.      His announcement opened a troubled final chapter in a remarkable three-term premi...
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair announced Thursday that he would leave office within the next 12 months, bending to pressure after an open rebellion in his own party.      His announcement opened a troubled final chapter in a remarkable three-term premiership in which he moved from absolute political dominance of a prosperous Britain to fighting off open mockery about his closeness to President Bush.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Sept. 7 - Prime Minister Tony Blair announced Thursday that he would leave office within the next 12 months, bending to pressure after an open rebellion in his own party.
